name: Kepler-249
scenarioDescription:
The Kepler-249 Exoplanetary System

Kepler-249 is a star with 0.3799999999999998 times the mass of the Sun, and 0.48 times its radius. It is located 624.39 light years away from the solar system.

Kepler-249 is known to have 3 exoplanets in orbit around it.

Kepler-249 b

Kepler-249 b was discovered by the Kepler observatory using the transit method. Its discovery was announced in 2014-03. Its semi-major axis is 0.04 astronomical units, as compared to Earth's which is 1 astronomical unit. It takes 3.31 Earth days to complete an orbit around its host star, Kepler-249.

The mass of Kepler-249 b is 1.18 times the mass of Earth. The radius of Kepler-249 b is 1.09 that of Earth. At less than 1.5 Earth masses, Kepler-249 b is a regular terrestrial planet, much like the terrestrial planets we find in our solar system, namely Mercury, Venus, Earth and Mars.

Kepler-249 c

Kepler-249 c was discovered by the Kepler observatory using the transit method. Its discovery was announced in 2014-03. Its semi-major axis is 0.06 astronomical units, as compared to Earth's which is 1 astronomical unit. It takes 7.11 Earth days to complete an orbit around its host star, Kepler-249.

The mass of Kepler-249 c is 2.60 times the mass of Earth. The radius of Kepler-249 c is 1.51 that of Earth. At 2.60 Earth masses, Kepler-249 c is a so called Super Earth. Super Earths could be terrestrial worlds like Earth, but they could also be ocean worlds or terrestrial worlds wrapped in a substantial atmosphere, in which case some refer to them as Mini Neptunes. No Super Earths are known to exist in our solar system, but if it exists, the so-called Planet Nine could very well be a super Earth, as it is hypothesized to have a mass between five and ten Earth masses.

Kepler-249 d

Kepler-249 d was discovered by the Kepler observatory using the transit method. Its discovery was announced in 2014-03. Its semi-major axis is 0.10 astronomical units, as compared to Earth's which is 1 astronomical unit. It takes 15.37 Earth days to complete an orbit around its host star, Kepler-249.

The mass of Kepler-249 d is 2.84 times the mass of Earth. The radius of Kepler-249 d is 1.57 that of Earth. At 2.84 Earth masses, Kepler-249 d is a so called Super Earth. Super Earths could be terrestrial worlds like Earth, but they could also be ocean worlds or terrestrial worlds wrapped in a substantial atmosphere, in which case some refer to them as Mini Neptunes. No Super Earths are known to exist in our solar system, but if it exists, the so-called Planet Nine could very well be a super Earth, as it is hypothesized to have a mass between five and ten Earth masses.
description: 3D visualisation and gravity simulation of the exoplanet system Kepler-249, which contains 3 planets and was discovered by Kepler.
